contentrichtext.text: In [[Greek mythology]], '''Philammon''' was the son of [[Chione (daughter of Daedalion)|Chione]] and [[Apollo (god)|Apollo]].<ref>[[Ovid]], ''Metamorphoses'', XI, 317.</ref> Some say his mother was [[Leuconoe]], daughter of [[Eosphoros]],<ref>[[Hyginus]], ''Fabulae'', 161</ref> or Philonis, daughter of either [[Deioneus|Deion]]<ref>[[Hyginus]], ''Fabulae'', 200</ref> or of Eosphoros and [[Cleoboea]].<ref>[[Conon (mythographer)|Conon]], ''Narrations'', 7</ref> He was an excellent musician, a talent he received from his father. By [[Argiope]], a [[nymph]] of Mount [[Parnassos]], he had two children, [[Eumolpus]] and [[Thamyris]].<ref>''[[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Bibliotheca]]'' 1. 3. 3.</ref><ref>[[Pausanias (geographer)|Pausanias]], ''Description of Greece'', 4. 33. 3</ref> Philammon was said to have established the tradition of the hymns celebrating the births of [[Leto]], [[Artemis]] and Apollo, written by himself, being performed by choruses of girls at [[Delphi]].<ref>[[Pseudo-Plutarch]], ''De Musica'', 3</ref> He was the second winner of the most ancient singing contest at Delphi, after [[Chrysothemis]] and before his son Thamyris.<ref>[[Pausanias (geographer)|Pausanias]], ''Description of Greece'', 10. 7. 2</ref> Some ascribe to him the foundation of the [[Lerna]]ean mysteries.<ref>[[Pausanias (geographer)|Pausanias]], ''Description of Greece'', 2. 37. 2</ref> He was also reported to have been among the [[Argonauts]].<ref>[[Scholia]] on [[Apollonius Rhodius]], ''Argonautica'', 1. 23</ref> ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.mythindex.com/greek-mythology/P/Philammon.html Myth Index - Philammon] {{Greek-myth-stub}} [[Category:Greek mythology]] [[Category:Offspring of Apollo]]
